div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalite met en adjudication la fourniture d'uniformes et antres articles d'habillement necessaires a ses differents service pour la duree de trois annees.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L. Eg. 100.
Le cahier des charges est deopose au Service de la Comptabili e Generale ou il peut etre consulte par les intereses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adres eas sous plicachate a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 5 Fevrier 1907.
Elles pourront egalement etre deporsees enreance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fourniitures d'uniformes et autres articles d'habulment."

Le cantionnement ou le recu d'nne banque, d'apres les condtions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis se arement au Service de la Comptabillite Generale avant l'overture des offres et au plus tard le 5 Fevrier 1907 a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci dessus sera ecartee.
L'Administratuer
(Signe) W.P. CHATAWAY
Alexandria, le 16 Fevrier 1907. 29383-3-3

div.head: THE GERMAN CRISIS.
div.p: In spite of the sinister motives' which are so freely imputed to us in the Fatherland, the, English public will continue to take a growing interest in the German electoral struggle German politics form an exceedingly perplexing study, and the group system on which their Parliamentary majorities are based leads occasionally to some very surprising combinations. In the recently dissolved Reichstag there were something like twenty separate "parties,' several of them, it is true, consisting of only a single representative. The most numerous section of all, the Catholic Centre, counted only 100 out of the total of 397 members, while the Social Democrats, who came next, had 81 But it should be added, that these 81 Socialists were returned by 3,000,000 votes, as against 1,900,000 cast for the Catholics' electoral anomalies are not confined to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. It is clear that the centrifugal tendency which kept Germany for so many years a more geographical expression has still to be eradicated. The German Empire has been unified by its Army and Navy, and stands. four square to foreign nations Internally, in the political arena at least, it is individualistic as ever, except in one quarter, where the solidarity and perfect electoral machinery of the Social Democrats form the main barrier to Imperial threats and cajolery. As the time for the polling draws, near the contest is narrowing itself down to a struggle between the Kaiser and the Socialists which may change the whole complexion of international politics.

The unprecedented efforts which are being put forward by the bureaucracy on behalf of their Imperial master are a significant indicatior of the light in which the elections are regarded at the heart of the Government. And in their extremity, the wire-pullers are directing their attention to the literary and professorial class, which has hitherto stood several) aloof from "Cessarism."

This, of course, says the "Globe," is tge meaning of the "lecture" which was recently delivered by Herr Dernberg, the Colonial Director, to the In tellectuals of Berlin. The theme, naturally enough, was the Gerrnan Colonial Empire, and though the discount seems of a somewhat elementary character when the class of audience is taken into consideration, Herr Dernberg succeeded in evoking no small measure of enthusiasm. And as a practical result, the meeting resolver to appoint a committee, which "without directly intervening in the agitation of parties, would endeavour to extend and deepen the appreciation of colonial policy and 'Welt politik' among the electorate." Some of the most distinguished names among the Prussiat Professoriate were promptly placed upon the list, and a campaign of lectures and leaflets is being rapidly prepared. We write in no carping spirit; this movement is projected on liner that are familiar to us Englishmen, and the enormous success of the German Navy League has shown what these voluttary organisations, can effect. Our chief criticism would be that, with a view to the present general election,the start has been made very late in the day. Moreover, the snare has been laid somewhat ostentatiously in the sight of the birds. The sudden enthusiasm of the Intellectuals for a colonial Empire is the subject of caustic comment in many of the German Radical papers ; and it is certainly somewhat remarkable that a sudden conversion should have been brought about by the academic and not very convincing arguments of the Colonial Director. Moreover, the Intellectuals are not held in any particular esteem just now by the leaders of active political thought in Germany, The fighting professors, like Mommsen and Virchow, have passed away, and no one has arisen to fill their place. The "Berliner Tageblatt" roundly accuses them of holding their tongues when the intellectual liberties of the nation were being menaced, and only coming forward when the beams of Court favour shine upon them.

An additional stimulus in favour of a spirited colonial policy is being sought in the alleged jealousy exhibited by Great Britain. And the English Press, which does not circulate, we should fancy, to any very alarming extent among the German electorate, is represented as trying to sow seeds of discord and to foment the spirit of social unrest which is so rampant in every rank of German society. The charge is ludicrous; but when we remember the credulity with which the lying tales about our soldiers were accepted during the Boer war, we feel that nothing is impossible. And the grossest calumnies against our armies and our Queen were those that found circulation among the Intellectuals and the Lutheran pastors ; Mommsen himself is a melancholy instance. Aa a nation we understand and sympathise with the German aspirations for a colonial Empire, though their present methods have been the source of no small inconvenience to ourselves, and of disturbance to tbs world at large. The Hottentot revolt in German West Africa has materially contributed to the growing unrest among the natives of that continent. The seixure of Kiaochao and the high-handed application of German rule to the Chinese led more than any single event to the Boxer rising. And if any serious endeavour is made to colonise Brazil with German emigrants, most dangerous complications with the United States are certain to ensue. Germany is known to regard the Dutch possessions in the East Indies as her ultimate heritage, and the forward school do not hesitate to hint that the British Empire overseas might do with a little lopping. We are justified, then, if we cast an anxious eye upon the proceedings of any newly-formed "League" in Germany. But if that great nation is ever to found a colonial Empire on the models which were held up by Herr Dernberg to the Intellectuals, there must be a total change in the principles of their colonial administration. Jolonics, above all things, require settlers, and no German who can possibly avoid it will submit to the petty annoyances and officialism which flourish wherever the German flag is, planted.

div.head: The Quay Casine.
div.p: A sitting was held yesterday of the Finance and Public Works Committee of the Alexandria Municipal Delegation and it was decided that Mr. George Ralli should furnish the plans of the new Quay Casino, of which he wants the concession, as well as a specification of the financial resources which he has at his disposal. These must be handed in within three months. The Municipality will then give decision for or against the project. Suez Bay.

div.head: Chezireh Palace Ball.
div.p: The manger Ghezireh Palace intimates that the invitations to the fancy dress ball on the 12th proxo have been issued thus early in order to afford ladies and gentlemen who intend to be present ample time to prepare their coatbmes. Guests presenting themselves in ordinary evening dress will be called upon, on entrance to the ball, to pay the sum of P.T. 40, and all such fines will be handed over to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

div.head: Stray Dogs in Cairo.
div.p: The "Journal du Caire" recently complained of the number of stray dogs in Cairo. That the allegations of our confrere are incorrect are proved by the following figures, which show how hard the Cairo police work on this most arduous duty of arresting stray or unmuzzled dogs. The number of these canine vagrants arrested in 1903 was 1,212 in 1904 2,200, in 1905 4,923 and in 1906 6,284. It will be seen that during 1906, approximately 570 were arrested montly, or 19 per diem. The statement that there "bandes de chiens sauvages" is a gross exaggeration.

div.head: English Variety Entertainment.
div.p: Alexandrians will soon have an opportunity of assisting at an English variety entertainment. Mr. Arthur Nelstone, who is described as "the world's greatest eccentric dancer," is on his way out here with a company wwhich will give an entertainment entitled "Novelty in all its Newness." Mr. Nelstone is not unknown in Egypt, having paid a previous visit to this country and met with success. Mr. Nelston made a great hit in last year's Drury Lane pantomime "Cindarella" as the "dancing sentry," contributing an extraordinarily eccentric dance. He is at present performing ini Malta, but comes on to Egypt in a few days.

div.head:
THE RUSSIAN AGITATION.
DEMONSTRATIONS IN CAIRO.
div.p: The excitement and tnrbolence which pre1 vailed at Alexandris on Saturday and Sunday proved to be contagions, and yesterday'n proceedings at Cairo did not pass off very trar quilly. The ball was set rolling at 12.50 I p.m., at the closing of the Boarse, when an
Italian orator clambered on a table in the bar Tof the Bourre and protested violently against

the arrest of the three R giang. He invited his apdience to follow & delegation to the Ministry of the Interior, and soop a bage crowd We werding its way down the Sbaris el-MA bekh When the Rnesian Diplomatic Ageney was reached in Sharia Soliman Pasba a halt was made. The crowd biged fervently, but there war no need for police intervention, and the mob then went on to the Russian Vice. Copsplate, where the crowd dumbered about a tbobsand. The police and fire brigade were in force and the latter had the bose ready. Mans. field Parha wanted to disperse the mob and ordered the mounted police to charge. In the disorder that engoed a police officer is said to bave drawn a revolver. He was attacked by the moh, but managed to escape from their fary. Meanwhile the Commandant of Police suoneeded in making the manifestors listen to reason, and it was decided to postpone further proceedings to the evening, when & meeting was held at the Nouveautés
beatre. The theatre was crowded and the following resolation was passed :

"Nommer personnages parmi les composants de la Commission Internationale, avec mandat da prier 8 B. Lord Cromer pour qu'il paisae obtenir un supplément d'instraction qui éclair. cisse d'une manière définitive la pré endae calpabilité des 3 malheureux Robee actuelle bent déten an."

A demonstration was expected yesterday afternoon on the departure from Alexandria of the 8 S. Imperator Nicolsa II. Strong police precautions were accordingly taken by the aqthorities to avoid any recurrence of the regrettable incidents of Sopday. As a matter of fact, all would-be demonstrators kept very carefully out of the way. A small crowd of aboat one hundred and fifty persons watched the departure of the vessel with apa by only tempered by the discomfort canced by a peculiarly bitter north-east wind.
The three Russian prisoners, we may remark, were not on the Imperator Nicholas II; wheber, if they had been, any demon. stration could bave occurred, seems to QB extremely doabtfal.

Several prominent members of the Enropean colonies have openly expressed their apneyapos at the statement that pide-tenths of the popolation of Alexandris ynpathised with the demonstrations, and declare that the responsibility for the attack on the Russian Cousalute must be laid at the door of a few misgaided leaders of a very small section of the respected Jewish community of Alexandria.

We are requested to state that the Greek community of Alexandris did not take any part in the recent disorders. Mr. Erumanuel Benachi, president of the Hellevio community of Alexındris, was successful in his efforts to prevent the membere of his colony from being dragged into the aftsir.
He sent a special deputation on Satorday and Sonday to the chief Greek establishments begging them to take no part in the demon atration.Not a sirgle Greek was arrested during the troubles.

div.head:
"BILLION DOLLAR SHIP."
ARRIVAL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: What has been termed by the American Press as the "billion dollar ship." the White Star liver Cedric, arrived at Alexandria th's morning, and landed over 250 passengers, who proreeded to Cairo by two special trains from he qawy.

Tbe White Star Line entertained a notable gathering aboard the Cedrio on the ove of the Bailine of the great "billion dollar ahip" from New York. It was the occasion of the firat sailing of so large a ship as the Cedrio,a mammo:b liner of 22,000 tone, for the Levant, that prompted the dinner given to the company's friends. There WAB A most enjoyable time in the gaily decorated maiu saloor, and a fine string orchestra rendered masic throughont the bar quet. The after-dinner speakers included Simeon Ford, who kept the audience about the tables in contiduous langhter; Judze Henry H. Gildersleeve, who told of his experieuses as a transatlantic traveller; Judge Harold Smith, the best kuown marine newspaper man in the East, who gave a brief outline of the growth of shipbuilding in the last few years; Louis Wyly and others.

The Cedrio called at the Azores and Gibraltar, as well as at Naples and Genoa, on route to Alexandria. It is the first time that the port of Alexandria has been visited by sach a great vessel as the Cedrio. There being no second cabin passengers on this trip of the Cedrio, the first cabin voyagers, of whom there were 475, had four magnificent promenade decks for their exclusive use during the delightful oraise

From a financial and industrial standpoint the Cedrio can aptly be called a "billion dollar ship" on this voyage to the Levant. Among ber passengers are hundreds of persons well known in the States. Great wealth was represented on the Cedric, and the versel, ander command of Captain Haddock, has the distinction of having carried the richest parsenger list over taken from New York by avy steamer.

div.head: PRINCE OF UDINA'S VISIT.
div.p: H.R.H. tbe Prince of Udina returned to Alexandria yesterday from Cairo. This morning his Highness visited the Italian rcbools in Alexandria, accompanied by the Italian Consol and Captain Marenco, commandant of the croiser Calabria.
The crew of the orniser are to be entertained on Saturday evening next at the Olympia music-ball.

div.head: CHEVALIER C. AQUILINA.
div.p: The many friends of Mr. Charles Aquilins, late of Messrs. The mua. Conk and Sin, and presently proprietor of the Carlton Hotel, will be pleased to hear that H.H. Pins X. bar created him a Knight of the Order of St. Gregory the Grent, in recognition of his nomerous deeds of charity, both bere and in Malta.

Chevalier Aquilina iz sn old resident hore: He came out in 1871. ard as president of the Malte e Benevolent society and the Society of St. Vincent de Paul, has rendered signal services to all who were in need of them. Ha was alao one of the founders and first president of the Maltore Victoria Bohool, an institution where to-day some 150 men and boys are taught the English langnage free of charge. As the "Emir el Hag," he condacted a pilgrimage of one thousand French pilgrims to Jørnsalem, in 1882, being then manager of Cook's in Palestine-n andartakiog redolent of orussding times. On arcival at the Holy City, the French Consal and the civic and bocloviastio authorities in their entirety met the pilgrims, and one sod all congratulated Me. Aqailina on his sno0883,- fest sooomplished in spite of the prediotion of the Branch Consol At Jerusalemw,ho had telegrapbed to the French Poreign Office to persuade the committee in Paris to divide the party into two sections for travelling through tha roaga country of Bamaria ; otherwise he feared a large number of the pilgrims would nevar 808 Jeroenlem. Nevertheless all reached their destination safely, within one hour of the advertised timg. Da that occasion the bead of the firm, the la & Mr. John Mason Cook, wired to Mr. Aquilina in Jerusalem, "Bravo, for everything Dincerning the pilgrimage." Bat it was during th, oholera of 1896 in Alexandria that Chevalier Aqailins's powers of organisation were pat to the soverest test. To combat the dresd pastilence amongst the Maltose colony and British sabjsota generally, Chevalier Aquilina founded an exegative committee, of which he was president, in conjunction with a central committee formed by the late Sir Charles Cooksop, British Copsal-Gagoral ia AlexAndria, and composed of several of our local Biglish residents of note. This central committee applied the fands, and with these th, Maltese committe, set to work to die. tributo relief in the form of medicine, food, and clothing, to the saffarers, Chevalier Aqui lina himself visiting the siok in their homes and superiotonding the sanitary mocarea nepeagitated. It is in recognition of these and many other note of hamanity performed both here and on his rooky island home that his Holiness has bestowed upon Mr. Aquilins this well merited title. We and all his friends will join in congratulating him on this occasion.

div.head: DISCOVERIES AT THEBES
div.p: QUEEN TIY'S TOMB.
(From QUE CORRESPONDENT.)

Lnzor, Monday. Although the season has only just began a magnificent discovery has already been made at Thebey, when, on the 9th irst, the tomb of Q seen Tiy, the wife of the third of the Amen. bosteps and the last of the great Emperors, was dincovered. The tomb, when foand, contained a broken raroophagas covered with gold leaf. The coffin ig very finel and contained the mommy but both had been smashed. Bvidently the tomb had been rifled by priests for the name of the Queen's son, tha beretio King Ikhnaton, bad been out out. The mommy still lies in the coffia and the stele is ontouched. It is not yet known whether the mommy has been rif.d. It will be necesary to make some scheme for patching op the coffia and some three weeks must elapse before anything can be toached. 1

This discovery is of immenre importance and the Ikhnaton reliefs found there are of the very best period of Tel el-Amarna art. The reliefs are embossed in gold. Unfortunately they have been mooh "spoilt by the water, which bas managed to percolate into the tomb. The sbape and style of the tomb are romarkably like that of Yoas and Taaa, the father and mother of Ty.

The discovery is dae to the researches financed and directe! by the distinguished American Bryptologist Mr. Theodore M. Davie. The autaal work is due to Mr. Ayrton. Mr. Weigall, of the Muroam Service, is conducting the inspection of the discovery on behalf of the Government,

The queen, whose tomb has just been dis. covered, was a remarkable woman and exerted considerable influence over the great king whose consort sb: wag. The quee's power sontinged throaghoat her husband's reigo and was the beginning of a remarkable era character ised by th» prominence of the queans in State affairs ard on pablio occasione, & pecnliarity which we find only under Amenhotep III. and his immediate predecessors. Scarabs and bits of glazed ware with the name of Amenhotep III. and Queen Tiy bave been discovered at Mycopræ Q 1000 Ty's husband died B.C. 1375 but as q neen-mother ber iufluence continued daring the reign of her son.

PIND AT DEIR EL BAHRI. A new tomb has jost been discovered at Deir el Babri daring the resahrches now hring conducted for the Egyptian Exploration Fand by Messrs. Neville and Hall. It appears to be the tomb of Mentahotep 11.. of the time of the Mantoboepa, who established the ani. veral supremacy of Thebes during the Eleventh Dynasty (B.C. 2168-2000). This king erected a small terraced temple under the a'iff, which atterward« served as a model fo. Qon Hatshepnt's besoiiful arnotuary be- | side it at Deir el-Bahri and here his tomb habaan found. It was evidently of a mortuary character and the reliefs on the walla depiot foreign people bringing tribute to the Pharaoh Its rnina, recently discovered, constitute tba oldest buildir g at Thebes.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S.
div.p: The Monday dances at Shepbeard's are more than ever popular this season, partly owing, no doubt, to the excellence of Mr. Bracale's orchestra, whose dance music is far and away better than any other in Cairo, military bands not excepted. Tbere was a great attendance in the Egyptian Hall last Monday evening ; and a fair pomber of outside visitors were present, in addition to those already stayiog in the hotel. Many pretty frocks were en evidence, a very lovely creation being that in pale grey chiffon trimmed with broad bands of moonlight silver sequins. Another beautital example of the latest mode had a skirt of delicately painted obiffon, the short Empire coat of satin being draped fiuba-wise across the bast, while the folds at the back were contigued in long sash like tails: there were narrow bands of sable, too, outlining the folds across the shoulders, from whence fell fragile sleeves of eh ffon and lace. Broad bands of pompadear ribbon gave a sabtle distinction to another dress of chiffon. These fell from the bagt to the edge of the shirt and were ganged round the wais", giving extra effect to the pretty figure of the wester, Another fragile frook was heavily embroidered with soarlot silken poppies on both skirt and corsage, and again another one of net and lace was most daintily decorated with | tiny ro•es and their foliage in softest colours. Various ladies were wearing those wild Indian head dresses of feathers, etc., which are fo much in vogue at present: doubtless one's eyes will soon grow aconstomed to these latest vag'ries of Mme La Mode ; bat in the meantime one can only gaze with fear and wonder at the extravagances of the up-todate coiffure

The great event of Shepheard's season, the ball cotillon, is fixed for Monday next; and all the Cairo world is preparing to be present. One of the most popalar winter visitors has been asked to sot as master of ceremonies and leader of the dotillon, and it is anticipated that this most popular of danges will prove a very great addition to the usual programme,

div.head:
SALT AND SODA CO.
EXTINCTION OF DEFERRED SHARES.
div.p: | Some arijqatments are going on in conneotion I with the affairs of the Bzyptian Bult aad Soda

Company, Limited. An extraordinary general meeting of the company was held at the com pany'a h-ad «ffice, Cairo, on Monday last, the 2 let inst., when a resolution which was pagup at tbe meeting of the company which bad already been held, on December 27 last. Waanbmitted for confirmation as a special resolo tion and passed. This resolation provides that, having regard to certain agreements, the capi. tal of the company be reduced to £450,000, and that auch reduction be effeated by cance'ling and extinguishing the 1,000 deferred shares in the company's ospital of £1 each and the capital paid up thereon.

The Bgyptian Salt and Soda Company, Limited, bad an original capital of £801.000 in 300 000 ordinary and 1,000 deferred shares of £1 each. It was increased in May, 1905, to £451,000 in 450,000 ordinary and 1,000 deferred shares of £l each, and now these deferred shares, after a very short life, are to be got rid of. The reasons, no doabt, are adequate ; but these sudden creations and sudden destrobtions might easily come to exert a disquieting inflaenor, especially when it is borde in mind that the Egyptian Government terminated the salt monopoly as irom January 1, 1906.

According to a return which bears the date of January 9, 1906, all the shares have been taken up, and £1 per sbare has been called up on 225.000 and £1 124. por share on 60,000, while £321,126 5«, has been received, including £126 58. paid on 445 forfeited abares. A total of 442,905 shares are represented by "hare warrants to bearer." Ol this amount warrants for $288,190 were irgoed between Jope 24, 1904, ar d January 9, 1906. Daring the same period share warrants for £280 were sorren. dered. There is nothing on the file to indicate which holders have exchanged their registered holdings for "share warrants." The principal registered holders of ordinary sbares at the date of the return were as below ; but it mast be borne in mind that, as already stated, many of these have probably been transformed into bearer warrants.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord and Lady Newborough anived at the Savoy Hotel, Cairs, yesterday. Lord Newborough is son of the Hon. Thounas Jobo Wyan and grandson of the 3rd Baron, whom he 800ceeded in 1888 at the age of fifteen. He is dess conded from John Wynn, who was Sheriff of Carnarvonshire in 1551 and 1560 and was standard besrer at the battle of Norwich 1549 ; and the first peer repra-ented Cir. narvonshire in Parliament. Lady Newbor uzb, whom he married in 1900. was Miss Grace Brood, and is denghter of Colonel Henry Montgomerie Carr, of Keotacky.

Sir Alexander Swette ham, whose name has come so prominently before thpublic in connection with ha Kingaton incident, has been Governor in Chief of Jamaica since 1904, and has had considerable colonial experience. He waa in the Ceylon Civil Service from 1868 to 1983, Receiver General at Cyprus from 1884 to 191, Auditor General of C-ylon from 1891 to 1-95, Colonial Seoretary of Singapore in 1895, A ting Governor, Straits Settlements, from 1898 to 1900, and Goveruor and Commanderin-Chief of Brirish Guiana from 1901 to 1904. Sir James is 61 years of age and hu been decorated for hi- colonial service. H, was made a K.C.M.G. in 1898.

| Mr. John Gerolimato, Briti-b Vice-Consnl at Harrar, who is staying in Cair, has had an interview with Lord Cromer. He is now at Al xandrie and will at y in E.yut for some time on account of his health.

div.head: GREEK TOBACCO IN EGYPT.
div.p: Next to Torkish, the tobacou grown in Greece is mocb in favour in E ypt, for acoording to the Customs returns tor December, 1906, of a total import of L.E. 64 857 worth of tobacco, Tarkey gapplied LB 31,965 and Greece LB. 19,754, while the total for the wbole year was, respectively, L E. 364,513 and LB. 214,979.

During December, the Greek imports were entirely of leaf tobacco, imported from Thessaly, whereas Turkey': quota included LE. 661 of Tambeki that delightful narcotio which is burned in the pargbild, or bookab. For the year jort ended, four million ckes of Greek tobacco were sold at prices ranging between 8 and 10 piastres the oke. There is to-day an old stock of 200,000 okes selling at that price; the new crop, however, is quoted at P.T. 12 the oke, first quality.

div.head: THE KINGSTON INCIDENT. REGRETTED IN ENGLAND. EXCHANGE OF CORDIAL TELEGRAMS

div.p: Messrs. Bcon and Taft have conferred with Mr. Roosevelt with reference to the Kingston incident. It is officially stated that the United States will not pay any attention to Sir James Swettenham's act, which they consider merely as that of an individual, and for which Great Britain can in no wise be held responsible. (Reuter)

Mr. Haldane wired to Mr. Root: "I have read in the newspapers what purports to be a latter from the Governor of Jamaica and can only say as one responsible for the troops in the island that I entertain deep gratitude for the generous assistance rendered by Admiral Davis during the most critical time."

Mr. Bacon replied that the President greatly apprecitates the cordial telegram. He is glad if the proziximity of the United States to Jamaica made it possible to be the slightest assistance If he can render further aid the President "earnestly hope that you will unhesitatingly call upon him knowing how cheerfully you would render such aid were the circumstatnces reveresed."

The Swettenham incident is all the more regretted in England in view of Admiral Davis's past friendliness with England. As a member of the Dogger Commission he turned the scale in favour of Great Britain. (Reuter)
The Mayor has received a telegram from the Mayor of Kingston dated 21st instant, appealing to the generosity of the American people for help which, he said, was most urgently needed. (Reuter)
H.M.S. Indefatigable has arrived and landed a quantity of supplies.
Sir J. Swettenham cabled to Mr. Root on the 20th instant that Jamaica was profoundly grateful for his sympathy and for the practifcal and kindly aid given by Admiral Davis and the squadron. (Feuter)

The Franco-Spanish squadron will withdraw tomorrow. One French warship will remain as a precautionary measure. (Reuter)
The Note concerted between France and Spain, announcing the racll of the squadrons from Morocco, expresses the hope that the Maghzen will facilitate the organisation of the police. (Havas)
The Government has apporved the bill for the completion of the Yunnan railway, and also a bill greatly facilitating the holding of services in churches. (Reuter)
Professor Martens, on a special mission from the Tsar, has started to visit the European capitals to arragne the preliminaries of a second Hague Conference. (Reuter)
Count Galliens has been appointed Italian Ambassador at Tokio. (Reuter)
The natives have murdered two Frenchman in the neighborhood of Djibouti. One was Ensign Perbien, who was going to Madagascar on board the Descartes. (Havas)
Arctic weather is being experienced throughout eastern and central Europe. Heavy falls of snow have taken place at Constantinople and Athens. (Reuter)

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA EXCAVATIONS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Dear sir, I should like to ascertain, through the medium of your valued paper, whether there is any explanation for the great quantity of broken pottery which is constatnly being excavated, and which can be seen on the surface of the ground in many places about Alexandria. I have in mind most particularly the ground about Ibrahimieh, which in many places is covered with the borken bits of red earthenware.
One reason I have heard was that the old Egyptians destroyed all their potterly yearly when the Nile ross.
I would be very glad to hear from others interested in the mattter.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administartion des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public qu'elle recevra jusqua'au 2 Mars 1907, des offres pour la fourniture de bois suivant la liste et les conditions dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire au bureau de Magsins de Gabbary (Alexandria) et au Service des Magasins a Boulac (Caire) contre paiement de 100 milllemes.
Etres meme temps que son offre, le soumission naire devra deposer L.E. 100 a titre de cautionement provisoire.
Les offres devront etres accompaguees d'une feuille de papier timbre de 30 milliemes. Elles serount adresses par la posts sous pli recommande a:
"Monsieru le Directeur General Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Le Caire."
et sous double envelopple, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour Bois."
L' Administartion ne s'engage pas a accepter l'offre la plus basse ni a donner suite aux soumissions presentees; elle se reserve le droit de diviser la comande.
Le Caire, la 16 Janvier 1907. 29366-2-1

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administation des Chemins de fer et des Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter la connaissance du public qu'elle recevra ju qu'an mercredi 8 Mars 1907, a midi, des offres pour l'schat des vieux barila dont l'Administation aurait a disposer au cours le l'annee 1907 et ce aux xonditions de cente lont on peut prendre connaissance aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) et au Bureau Centreal des Magasins a Boulac (Caire).
Les soumissionaires auront a joindre a lear offre au recepisse de versement de L.E. 20 (vingt Livres Egyptiennes) a titres de cautionement provisoire.
Les offres devront etre accompagnees d'une teuille de papier timbre de 30 milliemes. Sues seront adressees par la poste sous pli recommande a:
"Monsieur e Directure General Chemins de fer de l'Etat, Le Caire."
et sous double envveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour l'Achat de Vieux Barils."
L' Administation ne s'engage pas a accpeter l'offre la plus elevee, ni a donner suite aux soumissions presentees; elle se reserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 18 Janvier 1907. 29393-2-1

div.head: Prominent People Recommend the Remedy Pe-ru-ua.
Dr. Hartman's World Renowned Catarrh Medicine.
div.p: A Remedy for the Grip,

Gen. W. H. Parsons, 925 H St., N.W., Washington D.C. writes as follows: "Upon the recommendation of persons friends and many strong testimonials for the efficacy of Peruna in the treatment of the numerous sypmtoms of the grip with which I have been affected for four months past, I have been induced to undergo a treatment of this justly celebrated formula.

"I feel a decided change" for the better by its use for one week only, especially in toning up the stomach, and a consequent decided effect upon my appetite. "I therefore feel much encouraged that I am on the road to complete restoration.

"My numerous friends in Texas, where I have had the honor to command a brigade of her veteran cavalry in a four year war, may accept this voluntary testimonial to the merit of Peruna from a sense of obligation for its wonderful efficacy."
Pe-re-na a Good Tonic.

Gen. M.C. Butler, of South Carolina, writes from Washington, D.C., as follows: "I can recommend Peruna for dyspepsia and stomach trouble. "I have been using your medicine for a short period and I feel very much relieved. "It is indeed a wonderful medicine, and besides a good tonic."
Colds In the Head and Throat.
Chas. W. Bowman, 1st Lieut. and Adjt. 4th M.S. M. Cav. Vols., writes from Lanham, Md., as follows:

"Though somewhat averse to patent medicines, and still more averse to becoming a professional affidavit man, it seems only a plain duty in the present instance to add my experience to the columns already written concering the curative powers of Peruna. "I have been particularly benefitted by its use for colds in the head and throat. "I have been able to fully cure myself of a most severe attack in forty-eight hours by its use according to directioins. "I use it as a preventive whenever threatened with an attack.
"Members of my family also use it for like ailments.
"We are recommending is to our friends."

div.p: Brig. Gen. D. T. Kirby, Washington, D. C., writes concerning Peruna as follows: "Friends of mine having used your Peruna Catarrh cure with good results, I am impressed with its curative qualities, and can rrecommend it to those who are afflicted."

div.p: Rear-Admiral Hichborn, U.S. Navy, Washington, D.C., writes: "After the use of Peruna for a short period, I can now cheerfully recommend your valuable remedy to any one who is iin need of an invigorating tonic."

div.head: For Catarrh of the Stomach.
div.p: Gen. W.W. Duffeild, Washington, D.C. writes: "I have used Peruna in my family and have found it a valuable medicine and take pleasure in recommending it to all who suffer from catarrh of the stomach or who require a tonic of prompt efficacy."

div.head: DEAFNESS CAUSED BY CATARRH-RELIEVED BY PE-RU-NA.
div.p: Gen. A. M. Legg, writes from the Savings Bank Building, Washington, D.C. as follows:
"I take pleasure in endorsing the many recommendations I have heard and read of Peruna, because of having had knowledge of the truth of so many of them.
"We always tell our sick and alling friends of the remedies that we have learned, from experience, were good for us when alling in the same way, and we do it as a duty we feel that we owe them.
"Why is it any the less our duty to advise all the people we can when we know of a good and comparatively inexpensive remedy that makes many cures, and benefits in almost all causes?
"My own little personal experience of being relieved of deafness, caused by a siege of catarrh, warrants me in advising all the afflicted to just try Peruna."

div.head: For Kidney Trouble, Coughs, Colds, and Catarrh.
div.p: Gen. A.T. Hawley, 1336 25th St., M. W., Washington, D.C., writes: "I have used Peruna and find it very beneficial for kidney trouble, and especially good for coughs, colds, and catarrhal trouble."

div.head: Convinced of Pe-ru-na's Merit.
div.p: Brig. Gen. J. Floyd King, Washington, D.C. writes: "I unhesitatingly state that I am convinced Peruna is a medicine which will effect all that is claimed for its use." Those desirous of obtaining special directions with regard to the use of Peruna should write to Dr. S. B. Hartman, President of the Hartman Sanitarium, Columbus, Ohio.

div.head: When Other Remedies Failed Pe-ru-na Proved Efficacious
div.p: "I cannot too highly recommend your preparation for the relief of catarrhal troubles in their various forms. "Some members of my own family have used it with most gratifying results. "When other remedies failed, Peruna proved most effcacious and I cheerfully certify to its curative excellence."

div.head: Pe-ru-na a Standard Treatment For Catarrhal Diseases.
div.p: Mr. John C. Nelson, Dayton. Tenu., geologist and mining engineer, while a Captaiin in the Federal Army during the Civil War, contracted a case of rheumatism. This malady was constant and persistent, inducing the development of other ailments, which also became chronic. After taking a course of Peruna, Capt. Nelson writes: "Having been painfully afflicted with chronic rheumatism and the adjunctive complications for many years, and after having received many general and special treatments with only temporary relief, I read your scientific treatise on catarrhal diseases. "At my request you prescribed a special course of the Peruna remedies, which I closely followedm and am happy to report that my rheumatism and complicated ailments are subdued, and I feel young again at the age of 69 years. "reason will accpet your classification of catarrhal diseases as scientific and true, and the Peruna remedies as a standard treatment for them. I thank you heartily for your skilled and locial advice."

div.head: CENTRIFUGAL PUMPS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The general tendency, which has beccome very marked of recent years, towards the use of high-speed rotary movers has been the chief cause of the extended use of centrifugal pumps. The speed of the steam turbine and the electric motor renders it possible to drive such pumps at a good efficiency when direct coupled. In comman with other branches of mechanical science, however, the perfection of the design of these pumps has been rendered possible by the exact measurement of power whih the advent of electricity made practicable. The chief application of the centrifugal pump is for drainage, irrigation, and water works, and also for mine sinking and draining. With very high speeds for centrifugal pumps there happens a a phenomenon which is similar to the cavitation of propellers. In the high lift pumps, built of the De Laval steam turbine type, there is a single impeller, and such a phenomenal speed as 13,000 revolutions per minute has been recorded; at such a speed, however, the water cannot follow the rotating vanes, and it is therefore necessary to use an auxillary pump to feed the main pump. It is possible, however, with a multi-stage steam turbine to reduce the speed to some three thousand revolutions per minute, and to such a turbine the centrifugal pump may be direct coupledm and worked without the need of any auxillary. This gives a highly effiecient piece of apparatus which is low not only in first cost, but in maintencance. Some of the large drainage plants have had centrifugal pumps working most efficiently for many years. In Upper Egypt, at Khoderat, there are two centrifugal pumps each directly coupled to a steam-engine of 450 brake horse power, and capable of raising some 175 tons of water per minute against a head of 29-35ft. The combined efficiency of the engines and pumps, as recorded after careful tests, was proved to be 7-25 per %. In central stations and on steamships the centrifugal pump has proved itself to be most suitable for circulating condenser water.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LAS BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui d midi et demie.)
Peu d'affaires en general, sinon en nonvelles emissions qui flechissent l'United a 1 7/32 vendeurs et la Levico a 1 ½.
On a cepudant trate sur une assez large echalle l'Agricole qui finit a 9 5/8, apes avoir ete demandee a 9 21/32 pendant presque tonte la matinee.

La National Bank flechit a 28 1/8, la Ramleh a 6 3/8 l'Alexandria Water a 13 ½, la Biere d'Alexandrie a 230 la Privilegiee et 128 la Dividende, la Biere du Caire a 132 la Privilegiee et 68 la Dividende, la Cassa di Sconto a 277 l'ancienne et 272 la nouvelle, les Nungovich Hotels a 22 7/8. l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail a 35/3, la Land Investment a 5 l'action et 7 la fondateru, les Splendid Hotels a 4 1/16, l'Urbaine a 7 7/16. le Banco di Romoa a 114 ½, le Credit Franco-Egyptien a 6 3/8, et l'Aboukir a 44 shellings.

En revanche, les Dividendes Traamways d'Alexandria reprennent a 260, les Cotton Mills a 6, la Salt & Soda a 22, les Lots Turcs a 157. la Banque d'Athenes a 136. la Nile Land a 18. Is Delta Land a 4 13/32 et la Banque d'Orient a 135.

Le taux d'escompte, qui avait hausse a Londres a 5% vient de retomber a 4 7/8. De plus le taux de la Banque d'Allemagne a ete reduit da 7 a 6%. Co sont la des indices evidents de la detente monetaire.
A l'occasion du Courban Bairam la corbeille des valeurs restera fermes jusqu'a lundi prochain. Notre prochain bulletin ne paratra doncqua'a cette date.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUE
Le Caire, Maardi 22 Janvier.

Hier, le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres a ete encora eleve de 1/8 a 5 %; il est maintenantran niveau de l'esccompte officiel. An Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a regague 1/8 a 87 1/8. L'Unifiee est restee invariee a 102 ½. Le National Bank a perdu 1/8 a 28 3/8. L'Agricole et la Delta Light ssont demeurees inchangees a 9 ¾ et 12. La Daira a avance de 1/8 a 17 ¾.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien s'est maintenua 778. La Banque d'Athenes a retrograde de 1 franc a 136.

Iei, nous avons ea, ce matin encore, par suite de l'effet des nouvelles emissions, nu marche inactif et lourd, avec, accentuation de la tendance a la reaction sur presque toutes les devises de la cote.
La National Bank a faibli a 28 1/8-3/6 et l'Agricole a 9 5/8.
La Daira a flechi a 17 3/8 et la Behera a 40 ¾. La Nile Land est remontee a 17 ¾-18. L'Allotment a'est alourdi a 3 7/16-1/2 et as part a 139.

L'Immobiliere est revenue a 391. Les Enterprises Immobilieres et Travauxxesseont maintenues a 17 ¼; leur part a atteint 325 pour cloturer a 316 L'Epargne Immobiliere a ete ramenes a 3 9/16; as part a avance a 260. L'Express Nile a ete traitee a 5 9/16; des re alisations sur un marche tres resteint out ramene as part a 280. Les Cairo Suburban sont restes aux abords de 6. Les Cairo Suburban sont restes aux abords de 6. Les parts de la Societe Generale Egyptienne se sont raffermies a 109. Les parts Egyptian Mail sout revenues a 4 ½.
La Delta Light a faibli a 11 5/8. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire sout remontess a 294.
Dansle groups des valeurs hotelieres, les Egyptian out retrograde a 12 5/8-11/16, les Excelsior a 4 5/8 et leur part a 1 13/16. LEs National sont restes fermes a 3 15/16.

Parmi les petites valerus, la Delta Land s'est bieu teuue a 4 3/8, les New Egyptian a 28 sh. 3 acheteurs, avec un bon courant d'affaires, et les Maskereres a 20 sh. 9. Les Estates sout tasiers a 2 5/8 et leur part a 22. Los Salt and SOfa ont faibi a 21 sh. 3.

Dans la séance qui'il a tenue hier, le conseil d'administation de la Societe des Excelsior Hotels a resolu de deferer definitivement la question de la vente du square Soliman Pacha a une assemble generale qui sera conviquee pour la qw Fevrier prochain.

Cette decision dilatooire est rationnelle, en ce sena qu'ella est appelee a augmenter le benefice attendu de l'operiation, En effet, la SOciete est deja en presence de plusieurs offres brilliatntes pour la totalite aussi bien que pour des parties du terrain; or, tout porte a croire que d'ici au 12 Fevrier elle recevra des propositions plus avantageuses encore.
Comme on le voi; l'affaire se presente tout k fait favorablement et la resolution prise par le conseil ne peut tourner qu'au profit des actionnaires.

L'Espargne Immobiliere Ltd, continue a deployer la plus grande et la plus heureuse activite. Une bonne partis des terrains que la nouvelle Societe achetes est deja lotie, et lereastes est en vois de lotissement.

En attendant, la vente des parcelles marche a merveille, ce qui a'explique par les facilites exceptionnelles de paiement que la Societe accorde aux acquureurs. Ceux-ci ne sont tenus de verser qua la 7 % du montaut au comptant; 10% a 6 et 12 mois de date; 12% a 18 mois; 15% a 21 mois de date; 12% a 18 mois; 15% a 21 mois, et le solde en 27 aunnites, payables le 30 Novembre de cheque annes, avec un intere: de 4 ½ pour cent seulement a partir de ce jour. En l'etatm c'est presque une location avec l'avantage capital de devenir proprietaire en u n certain nombre d'anness.
Les plans de lotissement sont a la disposition du public et envoyes sur semande taite a la Societe.

En Bourse l'action est actnellement au despous du pair. Aussi est ce unce occasion unique pour s'interessser, a tres bon compte, a un titre qui promet d'atteindre, danus un bref de lai, un prix equivalent a sa valeur intrinseque reelle.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Cassa di Sconto e de Risparmio sout informes que les certiffcats provisoires de l'emission 1906 sont eobanges depuis hier contre les action definitives au porteur au siege central d'Alexandrie et a 1 succursale du Caire.

div.head: THE SNOWS OF THE NILE
div.p: DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI'S EXPLORATIONS IN AFRICA.

A distinguished gathering, including the King and Price of Wales, was present at the Queen's Hall, London, on Saturday week, when the Duke of the Abruzzi lectured before the Royal Geographical Socitey on "The Snows of the Nile." King Edward had previously entertained the royal explorer at dinner at Buckingham Palace.

At the command of his Majesty, Sir George Taubman Goldie, the head of the Royal Geographical Society, introduced the lecturer. He took occasion to say that, although his Majesty had frequently attended the meeting of their society when Price of Wales during the 40 years he had been vice-partron and though the late Queen had been patron during her long and glorious reing, this was the first time they had ever been honoured at a metting by the presence of the reigning Sovereign.

The Duke's lecture, which was delivered in perfect English and with notable fluency, was direct and practical in its language, and in brief, eminently adapted to the audience to which it was addressed. Several attempts, he explained, had been made by pervious explorers to ascend Ruwenzori on one side or the other, and before making his attempt he had carefully noted the information provided by his predecessors. The range was probably seen for the first time by Europeans by Sir S. Baker in 1864, and later by Gessi, in 1876. Neither traveller formed any exact idea of the importance of the range, however, and so Sir Henry Stanley was reserved the distinction of being its true discoverer. Stanley not only saw the mountain range to the south from Lake Albert, but in the following year traversed its western slopes. Stanley received many different answers to his inquiries as to the name locally given to these white mountains. Amongst the various nat ve designations, he chose that of Ruwenzori, which in the language of Mteora meant "rainmaker." Rowerzori was the only snowy range in the Nile basin, and therefore the only mountain that met Ptolemy's statement that the Niile was fed from mountian snows.

After describing the various attempts made to reach the summit of the monntain, his R oyal Highness told how he left. Naples on April 16 last year accompanied by several Italian zoo logists and botanists, in order to reach the mountain by June or July, when the rainfall was less persistent. After 54 days travel and a journey of 6,000 miles, they at last arrived at the not of the range, having travelled to Mombasa and thence overland, via Entebbe, by railway, caravan, and on too. On June 9 their little camp was all movement, and the Duke, with his Alpine guides and native porters, set ont to reach the watershed. At 13.780 ft., a greater height than the natives had ever reached before, the Duke was compeled to leave them. Clouds came up, and the party were forced to camp. Next day, favored by fine weather, the royal traveller and his party reached the crest of the mountain in three-quarters of an hour, over slightly crevassed snow slopes. "This three quarters of an hour,'' declared the Duke, teemed to me a century. and I pressed the guides to a pace which brought us all breathless to the top at dawn. The cloudless allowed us to see all the snowy peak which constitute the loftiest part of the chain." During the three following days, however, the party were unable further to explore the roots by which to reach the saddle between the two highest peaks, dark fog ard rain holding them prisoners in a narrow dungeon where their camp waa pitched. After great difficulties and trials the party reached the foot of the desired peaks, and after successfully negotiating a very steep snow slope mounted the ridge.

The attainment of the main object of his long and arduous journey was thus graphicallyy presented by the Duke:="We found at last a sort of ice chimney, 6ft. high, and Petigax, to climb it, had to plant his nailed boots on the head and shoulders of the unfortunate Ollier, who served him as a mounting block. The ridge was ours, and at the same time the top." Amid cheers, in which King Edward joined, the Duke went on to say:- "It was at 11.50." A fresh breeze blew from the southeast' the clouds swept past but a few yards under us, leaving clear only the two peaks that we had left and that on which we were standing. And to these summits, the only ones in view at this moment which crowned my efforts, I gave the names of Margherita and Alexandria, in order that, under the auspices of the two royal lades, the memory of two natiions mayy be handed down to posterity." Having unfolded the little glag which had been given to him at home by the Queen of Italy, he told how he fastened it to a staff planted on the highest point of the slowy dome to the cry of "Viva Margherita" 'Viva Alexandra!' Other peaks were named after the King and Queen of Italy, and after King Edward, while the names of previous explorers were used to distinguuuish the remainder. Altogether the range consisted of six principal groups. After being in the region of the one contians for thirty five days, during which time the Duke climbed x seen peaks the party party retraced their steps to the coast by the way they came, and landed at Marseilles on September 13.

A very practical feature of the electure was the admirable photographic pictures with which it was illustrated. These were afterwards deservedly commended by the King. The lecturer hid rather than advertised the perils of the mountaineering, but the photographs could not be silenced.

Before the applause which greeted the conclusion of the lecture had died down. King Edward rose and said: "I feel convinced that I am expressing the wishes of the Royal Geographical Society, as well as of this assemblage tonight, when I tender our thanks to His Royal Highness the Duke of the Abruzzi for the interesting lecture which he has just given us. He has travelled a long way for this purpose, and it has been no doubt a great strain on his voice. I feel sure that all of us will go home fully impressed with the admirable manner in which, this expedition was fitted and the successful results which it attained" (Cheers.) King Edward proceeded to refer to the previous attainments of the Duke of the Abruzzi, including his Polar Expedition, in the course of which one branch of his party reached a latitude little short of that attained by Commander Peary, and, in conclusion, His Majesty said:- "Our distinguisehd lecturer is fortunately for him, a young man,and I hope he has a loong life before him, in which he will continue to make explorations which are of such value both to science and geography. He belongs also to an illustrious and distinguished race- I am happy to think good friends and allies of ours. (Cheers) Above all things, he possesses great courage, great coolness and great will. This will, I am sure, carry him through any further expeditions or exploration he may make. I thank him agaiin, in the name of us all, for his lecture, and I wish him continued success in the course of any further expedition he may attempt."
His Majesty shook hands with the Duke, who, amid applause, briefly replied.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
